learning_outcomes.description: Evaluate the adaptation of specific crops and pastures (including cultivars/varieties/species) to diverse environmental conditions.
Using advanced concepts of plant physiology, explain management options available in dryland agricultural systems to ensure resource use efficiency and crop yield.
Evaluate and discuss strategies to mitigate herbicide resistance, and implement integrated approaches for effective weed and disease management for sustainable crop production.
Explain existing and alternative agricultural systems (including precision agriculture) in terms of sustainability of crop production systems.
Critically analyse management strategies to mitigate climate change effects in crop and pasture production systems.
Use a farming systems model (APSIM) to run simulations that vary for agronomic or genetic factors and interpret the results of these simulations.

assessments.task_description:
Agronomist’s Presentation on: The Impact of Climate Change on Agronomic Systems

Assignment Type: Case Study (Assignment 1)

Presentation Length: Oral presentation (10 min. & 3 min. Q&A) 

Weight: 30%

Task Overview

You are working as an agronomist and have been tasked with delivering a 10-minute presentation on how climate change is impacting agronomic systems and what can be done to enable farmers to adapt to the changing circumstances and ensure continued productivity. This task requires you to analyse historical and projected climate data, assess its impact on a specific cropping system, and propose scientifically justified agronomic strategies to mitigate risks.

You may focus on climate change impacts that are already occurring or projected for your chosen region, such as: Increased temperature; changes in rainfall patterns or drought frequency; extreme weather events; sea‑level rise and salinity etc.

Key Requirements:

For a specific location of your choice, your presentation must include:

  1. Describe climatic variability and climate change
  • Use historical and projected climate data to quantify key trends (e.g. temperature, rainfall, extremes).
  1. Assess impacts on a main cropping system
  • Explain the likely overall impact of climate change on crop production under current agronomic practice.
  • Analyse the specific effect of one climate factor (e.g. high temperature, drought, salinity) on crop growth and yield.
  1. Propose agronomic adaptations
  • Recommend at least three (3) agronomic modifications that could maintain or enhance productivity under future climate conditions, such as crop calendar (e.g. planting date, crop duration); cultivation or tillage method; crop variety or genotype; fertiliser and nutrient management; plant population or spacing; weed management.
  • All strategies must be scientifically justified.

Assessment Criteria:

Your presentation will be assessed on the quality and relevance of content in each of the three sections above, including:

  • Appropriate use of literature in relation to climate data 
  • Understanding of climate–crop relationships
  • Scientific justification of proposed agronomic strategies with a conclusion
  • Clarity, logic, and effectiveness of communication within the 10‑minute time limit

Your presentation must go beyond generic discussions of climate change and engage deeply with data interpretation, real-world case studies, and practical applications. While AI tools can assist with research, your analysis must include original observations, critical evaluation, and site-specific recommendations based on evidence.

The assessment and marking criteria sheet used for this course is on the blackboard site.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submission: All students should submit Powerpoint presentation PDF electronically through the Blackboard site. Ensure that your name is incorporated in the filename of the document.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
Agronomist’s 3-Minute Pitch on Sustainable Agriculture (Agronomic Systems)

Type: Case Study (Assignment 2)

Max length: 3-Minute Pitch (Oral Presentation) and written report (200-word reflection)

Task Description:

In this case study you are to assume that you are working as a senior agronomist for the Ministry of Agriculture. The Minister is concerned that the local agriculture may not be sustainable and asked you to develop a strategy for the development of more sustainable agriculture. The location is a sub-tropical to upper temperate region (You need to choose and specify the location/region that you are focussing on, such as southern Queensland), with distinct seasonal differences in weather, and some areas are based on annual crops while others are on perennial crops. By examining the situation further, it is realized that the existing system is unsustainable in the long term either because of difficulty in maintaining high crop yield or due to major economic (eg, high labour cost) and environmental (eg, soil erosion) issues. It is thus required to examine the possibility of changing from the established practices to a different system of production. (The proponents of change are aware of the social dimension of sustainability, but this aspect is beyond the scope of the present consultancy request)

Needs to be considered:

For example, if your chosen region was southern Queensland,

·      Summer crops are summer cereals (maize and grain sorghum), cotton and occasionally soybeans, peanuts, mungbeans or sunflowers.

·      Winter crops are wheat, barley, chickpeas and mungbeans.

·      Perennials may be sugarcane or fruit crops.

You need to choose the summer-winter annual cropping system and then define the agronomic system that is likely to be sustainable.

Your tasks as a senior agronomist are to:

i) Evaluate the sustainability of the existing system and comment on the Minister’s concern.

ii) Identify aspects of the existing system that lead to lack of sustainability from crop production, economic and environmental viewpoints.

iii) Establish production and resource management objectives that a revised system of production should meet.

iv) Assess alternative production systems that may be adopted in the area.

v) Recommend an alternative agronomic system and describe sequence/s of production of the range of crops you propose.

vi) Provide guidelines to the process of implementation of the revised system.

vii) Provide guidelines to the assessment of the effectiveness of the revised system in meeting the objectives proposed in (iii) above.

Your 3-minute pitch presentation will be assessed based on the content for each of the tasks mentioned above. The assessment and marking criteria used for this course is on the blackboard site.

As part of the assessment, you are also required to submit a 200-word reflection on the learnings from your active engagement in the 3 minute-pitch session.

Assessment Criteria

Your presentation will be assessed based on the following:

  1. Depth of analysis - Use of real-world data, critical thinking, and originality.
  2. Quality of data interpretation - Selection and meaningful discussion of datasets/literature.
  3. Scientific rigor - Justification of agronomic recommendations with empirical evidence.
  4. Presentation clarity and engagement - Logical flow, confident delivery, and professional articulation.

Final Notes

This task requires critical evaluation and original thought. AI tools can assist with research, but your interpretation, analysis, and recommendations must be unique and justified. Presentations that rely solely on generic AI-generated content without data interpretation or real-world engagement will receive lower grades.

By completing this task, you will develop essential communication skills in delivering complex scientific information concisely and persuasively - a key skill for agronomists in the field. Good luck! 

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

assessments.task_description:
Essay type exam questions will assess your knowledge on the content delivered in the two course modules, guest lectures and any other information discussed in the course.

The exam will be closed book - no written materials permitted and no calculators permitted. 

The exam will be an on-campus exam. Have your UQ student ID card available for ALL your exams. Students enrolled in In Person delivery must attend the exam in-person. 

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
